reasoning: The critique targets Section 3.5’s moral-uncertainty/intertheoretic-comparison discussion, specifically the paper’s tentative use of a “pairwise” method to argue unbounded views may deserve more weight. That section is supportive but not essential to the overall “no easy eutopia / most views are fussy” thesis, which is also defended via independent arguments (fragility/multiplicative factors, bounded/unbounded fussiness analysis). So centrality is moderate-low. The critique has some force: it correctly flags that pairwise comparisons rely on controversial cross-theory commensurability judgments and that different normalizations can flip recommendations, weakening any strong inference that unbounded views should loom largest. However, it overstates by saying the conclusion rests “entirely” on a manufactured bridge; the paper explicitly treats this as thorny and presents multiple methods without a decisive endorsement. It’s also partly incorrect to say utilitarianism and strict negative utilitarianism cannot ‘agree on the disvalue of bads’ in any sense—there can be agreement about the internal scaling of suffering (how bad bads are relative to bads) even if they disagree about compensation by goods. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: The pairwise comparison method fabricates intertheoretic agreement by stipulation
